steps.title: Stand up straight with your foot held out in front of you.
steps.content: Stand up straight with your foot held out in front of you. Your foot should be slightly off the floor with enough room to flex it in different directions. About 2–3 in (5.1–7.6 cm) should be enough. [1] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source If you feel unsteady, place your hand on a wall or a piece of sturdy furniture to help hold your balance. If you need to, you can also do this exercise sitting down.

steps.title: Point your toes forward as much as you can for about 15 seconds.
steps.content: Point your toes forward as much as you can for about 15 seconds. Keep your knee straight, and stretch your toes forward either as much as you can or until you feel discomfort. After about 15 seconds, relax your foot back to the neutral position. [2] X Research source If your ankle doesn’t pop, you can try again or stretch your ankle another direction.

steps.title: Repeat by pulling your toes back and turning your ankle from side to side.
steps.content: Repeat by pulling your toes back and turning your ankle from side to side. After each move, hold your foot in place for 15 seconds, then relax. Once your ankle pops, you can stop, or you can continue the stretches if you want to loosen your ankle even more. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source Your ankle will only pop about once every 20 minutes, so there’s no need to continue stretching unless you want to.

steps.title: Try rotating your ankle in circles if it didn’t pop already.
steps.content: Try rotating your ankle in circles if it didn’t pop already. Try 5 circles each of small, medium, and large rotations, first in one direction, then the other. [4] X Expert Source Neal Blitz, DPM, FACFAS Board Certified Podiatrist Expert Interview. 22 April 2020. If the stretches didn’t crack your ankle, the rotations may help it to pop. [5] X Trustworthy Source Cedars Sinai Hospital Website of one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If your ankle doesn’t pop after the rotations, let it rest before trying another method. Keep in mind that even if your ankles don't pop, these stretches are still good for improving the range of motion in your ankles. [6] X Expert Source Neal Blitz, DPM, FACFAS Board Certified Podiatrist Expert Interview. 22 April 2020.

steps.title: Switch legs and repeat if you want to crack both ankles.
steps.content: Switch legs and repeat if you want to crack both ankles. Sometimes, only one of your ankles might need to be cracked, in which case, you don’t have to switch to the other side. However, if you’ve loosened up the muscles in one ankle, it might be best to stretch the other one as well, even if it doesn’t crack. [7] X Trustworthy Source Cedars Sinai Hospital Website of one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Sit
steps.content: Sit in a chair so your feet don't touch the floor. Make sure you’re well-balanced and comfortable. You’ll be moving your feet for several minutes, and you don’t want to strain your back. [8] X Research source If you need to, shift so your weight is resting on the foot that’s still on the ground. You may be more comfortable in a chair with arms, so you can use your hands to help support your weight.

steps.title: Lift one leg into the air about 2–3 in (5.1–7.6 cm) off the ground.
steps.content: Lift one leg into the air about 2–3 in (5.1–7.6 cm) off the ground. For this exercise, you’ll be rotating your ankle in different directions until it cracks. Leave yourself plenty of room to move your foot around without running into the floor. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Trace the alphabet with your foot, leading with your big toe.
steps.content: Trace the alphabet with your foot, leading with your big toe. By tracing the alphabet, you’ll be forcing your ankle into a variety of different angles and movements that you might not normally perform. One of these motions may be just the thing to crack your ankle. [10] X Research source Repeat the alphabet 1-3 times as necessary. This works a lot of the external and intrinsic muscles that control your ankle and foot. [11] X Expert Source Neal Blitz, DPM, FACFAS Board Certified Podiatrist Expert Interview. 22 April 2020.

steps.title: Switch and repeat with the other foot.
steps.content: Switch and repeat with the other foot. If you want to crack both of your ankles, shift your weight in your chair, return the first foot to the floor, and lift the other foot. Even if your ankle doesn’t crack, it’s always a good idea to limber up both sides of your body evenly. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Sit with your legs crossed and put one foot on the opposite knee.
steps.content: Sit with your legs crossed and put one foot on the opposite knee. For this exercise, you’ll be most comfortable—and stable—if you sit on the floor. If sitting directly on the floor is uncomfortable, you can sit on a cushion or a pile of blankets. [13] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You may also be able to perform this exercise sitting on a bed or a couch.

steps.title: Pick one foot up and place it on top of the opposite knee.
steps.content: Pick one foot up and place it on top of the opposite knee. This will be a sort of modified lotus pose. The outside of your foot should rest on the top of the opposite knee. This position should feel comfortable and not strained. [14] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you feel any discomfort in your ankle, knee, or lower back, stop right away.

steps.title: Place one hand on top of your ankle and grasp your foot with the other.
steps.content: Place one hand on top of your ankle and grasp your foot with the other. You’ll be using your hands to manipulate your ankle, so be sure you have a good grip on your foot. Hold it firmly, but do not squeeze so tightly that it’s uncomfortable. [15] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Guide your foot in circular rotations, first one way, then the other.
steps.content: Guide your foot in circular rotations, first one way, then the other. Make sure you stretch your ankle gently, in slow circles, keeping your ankle extended as far as you comfortably can. However, don’t force your ankle to the point of discomfort. [16] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source If you need to, you can repeat on the other foot.
